water.title: Water
water.description: Essential for all known forms of life. A polar molecule capable of dissolving many substances.

details.origin: Formed in the interstellar medium and abundant in the solar system. Earth's water likely came from asteroids and comets.
details.structure: Bent molecular geometry with H-O-H angle of 104.5°. Displays hydrogen bonding.
details.fun_fact: Water is the only common substance found naturally in all three distinct states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas.
details.properties: Universal Solvent, High Heat Capacity, High Surface Tension.

salt.title: Sodium Chloride
salt.description: Common table salt. Essential for electrolyte balance in animals and seasoning food.

details.origin: Extracted from salt mines or by evaporating seawater. Historically used as currency.
details.structure: Giant ionic lattice structure. Each Na+ ion is surrounded by 6 Cl- ions.
details.fun_fact: Sodium is an explode-in-water metal, Chlorine is a toxic gas, but together they are edible salt!
details.properties: Soluble in water, High melting point, Conducts electricity when molten.

photosynthesis.title: Photosynthesis
photosynthesis.description: The process by which plants use sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide to create oxygen and energy in the form of sugar.

details.origin: Evolved ~3 billion years ago in cyanobacteria, oxygenating Earth's atmosphere.
details.process: Occurs in chloroplasts using chlorophyll pigment.
reaction_steps: 1. Light Absorption: Chlorophyll absorbs sunlight photons.
2. Water Splitting (Photolysis): Water is broken into O2, H+, and e-.
3. Carbon Fixation (Calvin Cycle): CO2 is converted into Glucose (sugar).
details.fun_fact: This single process is responsible for nearly all oxygen in our atmosphere.

combustion.title: Combustion
combustion.description: A high-temperature exothermic redox chemical reaction between a fuel (like methane) and an oxidant (oxygen).

details.origin: Fire was discovered by early humans ~1.5 million years ago, revolutionizing diet and protection.
details.process: Rapid oxidation generating heat and light.
reaction_steps: 1. Ignition: Heat must be applied to break bonds (Activation Energy).
2. Reaction: Fuel (C, H) reacts with Oxygen (O2).
3. Release: Formation of CO2 and H2O releases massive energy.
details.fun_fact: Complete combustion produces blue flame; incomplete produces yellow/orange (soot).

sulfuric_acid.title: Sulfuric Acid
sulfuric_acid.description: A strong mineral acid with many industrial applications, including fertilizer production and refining oil.

details.origin: Known to medieval alchemists as 'oil of vitriol'.
details.structure: Tetrahedral geometry at Sulfur. Strong dehydrating agent.
details.fun_fact: It is the most produced chemical in the world by volume.
details.properties: Highly Corrosive, Hygroscopic (absorbs water from air).

glucose.title: Glucose
glucose.description: A simple sugar that is an important energy source in living organisms and is a component of many carbohydrates.

details.origin: Discovered by Andreas Marggraf in 1747 from raisins.
details.structure: Can exist as a linear chain or a ring (cyclic) structure.
details.fun_fact: The brain uses about 20% of the body's total glucose energy.

co2.title: Carbon Dioxide
co2.description: A colorless gas produced by burning carbon and organic compounds and by respiration.

details.origin: First gas to be described as a discrete substance by Jan Baptist van Helmont (17th century).
details.fun_fact: Solid CO2 is called 'Dry Ice' because it sublimates directly to gas.

hcl.title: Hydrochloric Acid
hcl.description: A strong, corrosive acid that is widely used in industry and found naturally in gastric acid.

details.origin: Historically called 'muriatic acid' or 'spirits of salt'.
details.structure: Diatomic molecule HCl. Fully dissociates in water.
details.fun_fact: Your stomach produces this acid to digest food (pH 1.5-3.5)!

naoh.title: Sodium Hydroxide
naoh.description: Also known as lye and caustic soda, an inorganic compound with the formula NaOH.

details.origin: Traditionally obtained by leaching ashes (potash).
details.structure: Ionic crystal containing Na+ and OH- ions.
details.fun_fact: Used to make soap, paper, and even pretzels (in food grade)!

ammonia.title: Ammonia
ammonia.description: A compound of nitrogen and hydrogen with the formula NH3. A colorless gas with a characteristic pungent smell.

details.origin: Named after the Temple of Jupiter Ammon in Libya where ammonium salts were collected.
details.fun_fact: About 80% or more of ammonia produced is used for fertilizing agricultural crops.

nitric_acid.title: Nitric Acid
nitric_acid.description: A highly corrosive mineral acid. The pure compound is colorless, but older samples tend to be yellow.

details.origin: First mentioned in the 8th century by Jabir ibn Hayyan.
details.fun_fact: It is mainly used for the production of fertilizers and explosives (TNT).

baking_soda.title: Baking Soda
baking_soda.description: Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3), widely used in baking.

details.origin: First produced by French chemist Nicolas Leblanc in 1791.
details.fun_fact: It releases CO2 gas when heated or mixed with acid, helping cakes rise.

ethanol.title: Ethanol
ethanol.description: A volatile, flammable, colorless liquid with a slight characteristic odor.

details.origin: Fermentation of sugars is one of the earliest biotechnologies employed by humans.
details.fun_fact: It is the psychoactive ingredient in alcoholic drinks and also a biofuel.

butane.title: Butane
butane.description: An organic compound with the formula C4H10 that is an alkane with four carbon atoms.

details.origin: Discovered by Edward Frankland in 1849.
details.fun_fact: It is commonly used as fuel for lighters and portable stoves.

methane.title: Methane
methane.description: A chemical compound with the chemical formula CH4 (one atom of carbon and four atoms of hydrogen).

details.origin: Alessandro Volta discovered methane in the reeds of Lake Maggiore in 1776.
details.fun_fact: It is the main constituent of natural gas and a potent greenhouse gas.

nitrogen.title: Nitrogen Gas
nitrogen.description: A colorless, odorless unreactive gas that forms about 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

details.origin: Discovered by Daniel Rutherford in 1772.
details.structure: Diatomic molecule with a very strong triple bond.
details.fun_fact: Liquid nitrogen is used for cryotherapy and making smooth ice cream instantly.

oxygen.title: Oxygen Gas
oxygen.description: A highly reactive nonmetal, and an oxidizing agent that readily forms oxides with most elements.

details.origin: Independently discovered by Scheele and Priestley in the 1770s.
details.fun_fact: About 50-80% of the oxygen production on Earth comes from the ocean (plankton).

respiration.title: Cellular Respiration
respiration.description: Metabolic reactions that take place in the cells of organisms to convert biochemical energy from nutrients into ATP.

details.process: Glycolysis -> Krebs Cycle -> Electron Transport Chain.
reaction_steps: 3. Waste products are CO2 and Water.
details.fun_fact: It is effectively the reverse of photosynthesis.

neutralization.title: Neutralization
neutralization.description: A chemical reaction in which acid and a base react quantitatively with each other.

reaction_steps: 1. Protons (H+) from acid react with Hydroxide (OH-) from base.
details.fun_fact: This reaction is used to treat acidic soil or neutralize stomach acid (antacids).

decomposition_h2o2.title: H₂O₂ Decomposition
decomposition_h2o2.description: The breakdown of hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen, often catalyzed.

details.process: Catalytic decomposition (e.g., using Potassium Iodide or Yeast).
details.fun_fact: Famous as the 'Elephant Toothpaste' experiment due to rapid foam production.

synthesis_water.title: Synthesis of Water
synthesis_water.description: The explosive reaction between hydrogen and oxygen to form water.

details.fun_fact: This reaction powers the main engines of the Space Shuttle.

acetic_acid.title: Acetic Acid
acetic_acid.description: An organic acid that gives vinegar its sour taste and pungent smell.

details.origin: Known since antiquity as the main component of vinegar.
details.fun_fact: Glacial acetic acid freezes at 16.6°C (61.9°F), forming crystals that look like ice.

calcium_carbonate.title: Calcium Carbonate
calcium_carbonate.description: A chemical compound with the formula CaCO3. It is a common substance found in rocks.

details.origin: Main component of pearls and the shells of marine organisms.
details.fun_fact: It is the active ingredient in agricultural lime and is created when hard water evaporates.

benzene.title: Benzene
benzene.description: An organic chemical compound with the molecular formula C6H6. The benzene molecule is composed of six carbon atoms joined in a planar ring.

details.origin: Michael Faraday first isolated benzene in 1825.
details.structure: Aromatic ring with delocalized pi electrons.
details.fun_fact: Its ring structure came to Kekulé in a dream of a snake biting its own tail (Ouroboros).

fermentation.title: Fermentation
fermentation.description: A metabolic process that produces chemical changes in organic substrates through the action of enzymes.

details.process: Anaerobic conversion of sugar to ethanol and CO2 (in yeast).
details.fun_fact: Louis Pasteur was the first zymologist (scientist who studies fermentation).

esterification.title: Esterification
esterification.description: The chemical reaction between an acid and an alcohol which forms an ester.

details.fun_fact: Esters are responsible for the pleasant fruity smells of bananas, pears, and pineapples.

aspirin.title: Aspirin
aspirin.description: Acetylsalicylic acid, a medication used to treat pain, fever, or inflammation.

details.origin: First synthesized by Felix Hoffmann at Bayer in 1897.
details.structure: Contains an ester group and a carboxylic acid group.
details.fun_fact: It is one of the most widely used medications globally, with an estimated 40,000 tonnes consumed each year.

caffeine.title: Caffeine
caffeine.description: A central nervous system stimulant of the methylxanthine class.

details.origin: First isolated by Friedlieb Ferdinand Runge in 1819.
details.fun_fact: In plants, caffeine acts as a natural pesticide that paralyzes and kills insects feeding on the plant.

ozone.title: Ozone
ozone.description: An inorganic molecule with the chemical formula O3. It is a pale blue gas with a distinctively pungent smell.

details.origin: Discovered by Christian Friedrich Schönbein in 1840.
details.fun_fact: The Ozone Layer absorbs most of the Sun's ultraviolet radiation, protecting life on Earth.

haber_process.title: Haber Process
haber_process.description: An industrial process for producing ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen.

details.process: High pressure and temperature with iron catalyst.
details.fun_fact: This process sustains about 40% of the world's population through fertilizer production.

saponification.title: Saponification
saponification.description: A process that involves conversion of fat, oil, or lipid into soap and alcohol by the action of heat in the presence of aqueous alkali.

details.fun_fact: The name comes from the Latin 'sapo', meaning soap.

rusting.title: Rusting (Oxidation)
rusting.description: An oxidation reaction. Iron reacts with water and oxygen to form hydrated iron(III) oxide (rust).

details.origin: The degradation of iron artifacts is a major challenge in archaeology.
reaction_steps: 1. Anodic Site: Iron loses electrons (Fe -> Fe2+ + 2e-).
2. Cathodic Site: Oxygen accepts electrons with water (O2 + 4e- + 2H2O -> 4OH-).
3. Formation: Fe2+ and OH- react to form Iron(III) hydroxides, drying to Rust.
details.fun_fact: Salt water accelerates rusting because ions increase conductivity.

privacy.intro: This Privacy Policy explains how ADSEGOM LTD collects, uses, and discloses information about you when you use ChemSolver.

section_1.content_b:

• Device Information: Model, OS version.

section_2.title: 2. How We Use Your Information
section_2.content:
• Provide and improve the App.
• Process AI Requests: To identify chemical elements and provide educational context as requested.
• Image Usage: We use the data in your uploaded photos solely to analyze the chemical data you request. We do not use this data for authentication or tracking.
• Data is shared with AI providers only for the duration of the analysis process.

• Respond to support requests.

section_3.content: We do not sell your personal data. We share data only with AI Providers (for processing), Backend Infrastructure (for storage), and for Legal Requirements.

section_4.content:
• Images are converted and sent to AI providers securely.
• Retention: We do NOT permanently store your source images after processing.
• Data Policy: We do not sell, trade, or transfer your image data to third parties.
• We retain anonymous account info while active.

section_5.title: 5. Data Security
section_5.content: We use industry-standard security measures. However, no internet transmission is 100% secure.

section_6.title: 6. Deletion of Data
section_6.content: You may request deletion of your account and data within the app or by contacting us.

section_7.title: 7. Children's Privacy
section_7.content: The App is not intended for children under 18. We do not knowingly collect info from children.

section_8.title: 8. Changes to Policy
section_8.content: We may update this policy. We will notify you of changes.

section_9.title: 9. Contact Us
section_9.content: If you have questions, please contact us at info@rizzflows.com (ADSEGOM LTD).
